jonbarril wrote:
> Is there any way to "catch" a compile error for failure assertion?
> 
> I have classes whose methods accept specific combinations of generic
> parameter types, and I want to test to make sure that the bad
> combinations truly generate compile errors.  I have not been able to
> figure out an automatic way to test for a compile error as part of my
> JUnit test suite.  Currently, I have to manually uncomment the bad
> code lines to "test" if they are still bad compiles.  Is there a
> better way?

If I understand your scenario correctly, you're testing a feature of the 
1.5 language. That's like testing whether the statement 'int i = "foo"' 
will compile. Why must that be tested?

That said, I suppose that you could rig up a test that calls 
java.lang.Runtime.exec("javac " + filename) on a number of pre-existing 
*.java files that will trigger the expected compilation error. You'd 
have to examine the Process object that's returned by exec(), wait for 
it to finish, then assert its exit value and/or error and output 
streams. I wouldn't want to be the one who writes that test, though.
